On Tue, 8 Jun 2004, Jonathan Oddy wrote:

> J. B. wrote:
> > I don't like to write End to End tests; however, when someone returns
> > me a defect, I have to admit that I missed something, and to punish
> > myself, I do things I don't like. I do this:
>
> I spend a lot of time punishing myself:( (though not as much as I used to!)

I used not to do much in the way of end-to-end testing, but in the last
year or so I've completely revised my approach. End-to-end testing is a
great way to write a spec, if you can write a set of readable end-to-end
test cases, it will discover problems you can't discover otherwise, and
it will sometimes reduce the need for unit testing.

If writing some sort of test is painful, you're writing it wrong. Try to
find a better way. (Not that I've yet found better ways in many cases,
but I'm always trying.)

cjs
